member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.AmazonFMSRequest
member.summary: Base class for FMS operation requests.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.AssociateAdminAccountRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the AssociateAdminAccount operation. Sets the AWS Firewall Manager administrator account. AWS Firewall Manager must be associated with the master account of your AWS organization or associated with a member account that has the appropriate permissions. If the account ID that you submit is not an AWS Organizations master account, AWS Firewall Manager will set the appropriate permissions for the given member account.
The account that you associate with AWS Firewall Manager is called the AWS Firewall Manager administrator account.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.AssociateAdminAccountRequest.AdminAccount
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property AdminAccount.
The AWS account ID to associate with AWS Firewall Manager as the AWS Firewall Manager administrator account. This can be an AWS Organizations master account or a member account. For more information about AWS Organizations and master accounts, see Managing the AWS Accounts in Your Organization.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.AssociateAdminAccountResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the AssociateAdminAccount operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.ComplianceViolator
member.summary: Details of the resource that is not protected by the policy.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.ComplianceViolator.ResourceId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ResourceId.
The resource ID.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.ComplianceViolator.ResourceType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ResourceType.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.ComplianceViolator.ViolationReason
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ViolationReason.
The reason that the resource is not protected by the policy.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.DeleteNotificationChannelRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the DeleteNotificationChannel operation. Deletes an AWS Firewall Manager association with the IAM role and the Amazon Simple Notification Service (SNS) topic that is used to record AWS Firewall Manager SNS logs.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.DeleteNotificationChannelResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the DeleteNotificationChannel operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.DeletePolicyRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the DeletePolicy operation. Permanently deletes an AWS Firewall Manager policy.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.DeletePolicyRequest.DeleteAllPolicyResources
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property DeleteAllPolicyResources.
If True, the request performs cleanup according to the policy type.
For AWS WAF and Shield Advanced policies, the cleanup does the following:
Deletes rule groups created by AWS Firewall Manager
Removes web ACLs from in-scope resources
Deletes web ACLs that contain no rules or rule groups
For security group policies, the cleanup does the following for each security group in the policy:
Disassociates the security group from in-scope resources
Deletes the security group if it was created through Firewall Manager and if it's no longer associated with any resources through another policy
After the cleanup, in-scope resources are no longer protected by web ACLs in this policy. Protection of out-of-scope resources remains unchanged. Scope is determined by tags that you create and accounts that you associate with the policy. When creating the policy, if you specify that only resources in specific accounts or with specific tags are in scope of the policy, those accounts and resources are handled by the policy. All others are out of scope. If you don't specify tags or accounts, all resources are in scope.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.DeletePolicyRequest.PolicyId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property PolicyId.
The ID of the policy that you want to delete. PolicyId is returned by PutPolicy and by ListPolicies.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.DeletePolicyResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the DeletePolicy operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.DisassociateAdminAccountRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the DisassociateAdminAccount operation. Disassociates the account that has been set as the AWS Firewall Manager administrator account. To set a different account as the administrator account, you must submit an AssociateAdminAccount request.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.DisassociateAdminAccountResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the DisassociateAdminAccount operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.EvaluationResult
member.summary: Describes the compliance status for the account. An account is considered noncompliant if it includes resources that are not protected by the specified policy or that don't comply with the policy.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.EvaluationResult.ComplianceStatus
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ComplianceStatus.
Describes an AWS account's compliance with the AWS Firewall Manager policy.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.EvaluationResult.EvaluationLimitExceeded
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property EvaluationLimitExceeded.
Indicates that over 100 resources are noncompliant with the AWS Firewall Manager policy.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.EvaluationResult.ViolatorCount
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ViolatorCount.
The number of resources that are noncompliant with the specified policy. For AWS WAF and Shield Advanced policies, a resource is considered noncompliant if it is not associated with the policy. For security group policies, a resource is considered noncompliant if it doesn't comply with the rules of the policy and remediation is disabled or not possible.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetAdminAccountRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the GetAdminAccount operation. Returns the AWS Organizations master account that is associated with AWS Firewall Manager as the AWS Firewall Manager administrator.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetAdminAccountResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the GetAdminAccount operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetAdminAccountResponse.AdminAccount
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property AdminAccount.
The AWS account that is set as the AWS Firewall Manager administrator.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetAdminAccountResponse.RoleStatus
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RoleStatus.
The status of the AWS account that you set as the AWS Firewall Manager administrator.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetComplianceDetailRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the GetComplianceDetail operation. Returns detailed compliance information about the specified member account. Details include resources that are in and out of compliance with the specified policy. Resources are considered noncompliant for AWS WAF and Shield Advanced policies if the specified policy has not been applied to them. Resources are considered noncompliant for security group policies if they are in scope of the policy, they violate one or more of the policy rules, and remediation is disabled or not possible.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetComplianceDetailRequest.MemberAccount
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MemberAccount.
The AWS account that owns the resources that you want to get the details for.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetComplianceDetailRequest.PolicyId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property PolicyId.
The ID of the policy that you want to get the details for. PolicyId is returned by PutPolicy and by ListPolicies.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetComplianceDetailResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the GetComplianceDetail operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetComplianceDetailResponse.PolicyComplianceDetail
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property PolicyComplianceDetail.
Information about the resources and the policy that you specified in the GetComplianceDetail request.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetNotificationChannelResponse.SnsTopicArn

member.summary:

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetPolicyResponse.PolicyArn

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetProtectionStatusRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the GetProtectionStatus operation. If you created a Shield Advanced policy, returns policy-level attack summary information in the event of a potential DDoS attack. Other policy types are currently unsupported.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetProtectionStatusRequest.EndTime
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property EndTime.
The end of the time period to query for the attacks. This is a timestamp type. The request syntax listing indicates a number type because the default used by AWS Firewall Manager is Unix time in seconds. However, any valid timestamp format is allowed.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetProtectionStatusRequest.MaxResults
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxResults.
Specifies the number of objects that you want AWS Firewall Manager to return for this request. If you have more objects than the number that you specify for MaxResults, the response includes a NextToken value that you can use to get another batch of objects.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetProtectionStatusRequest.MemberAccountId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MemberAccountId.
The AWS account that is in scope of the policy that you want to get the details for.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetProtectionStatusRequest.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
If you specify a value for MaxResults and you have more objects than the number that you specify for MaxResults, AWS Firewall Manager returns a NextToken value in the response, which you can use to retrieve another group of objects. For the second and subsequent GetProtectionStatus requests, specify the value of NextToken from the previous response to get information about another batch of objects.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetProtectionStatusRequest.PolicyId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property PolicyId.
The ID of the policy for which you want to get the attack information.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetProtectionStatusRequest.StartTime
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property StartTime.
The start of the time period to query for the attacks. This is a timestamp type. The request syntax listing indicates a number type because the default used by AWS Firewall Manager is Unix time in seconds. However, any valid timestamp format is allowed.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetProtectionStatusResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the GetProtectionStatus operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetProtectionStatusResponse.AdminAccountId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property AdminAccountId.
The ID of the AWS Firewall administrator account for this policy.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetProtectionStatusResponse.Data
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Data.
Details about the attack, including the following:
Attack type
Account ID
ARN of the resource attacked
Start time of the attack
End time of the attack (ongoing attacks will not have an end time)
The details are in JSON format.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetProtectionStatusResponse.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
If you have more objects than the number that you specified for MaxResults in the request, the response includes a NextToken value. To list more objects, submit another GetProtectionStatus request, and specify the NextToken value from the response in the NextToken value in the next request.
AWS SDKs provide auto-pagination that identify NextToken in a response and make subsequent request calls automatically on your behalf. However, this feature is not supported by GetProtectionStatus. You must submit subsequent requests with NextToken using your own processes.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.GetProtectionStatusResponse.ServiceType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ServiceType.
The service type that is protected by the policy. Currently, this is always SHIELD_ADVANCED.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.ListComplianceStatusRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the ListComplianceStatus operation. Returns an array of PolicyComplianceStatus objects in the response. Use PolicyComplianceStatus to get a summary of which member accounts are protected by the specified policy.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.ListComplianceStatusRequest.MaxResults
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxResults.
Specifies the number of PolicyComplianceStatus objects that you want AWS Firewall Manager to return for this request. If you have more PolicyComplianceStatus objects than the number that you specify for MaxResults, the response includes a NextToken value that you can use to get another batch of PolicyComplianceStatus objects.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.ListComplianceStatusRequest.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
If you specify a value for MaxResults and you have more PolicyComplianceStatus objects than the number that you specify for MaxResults, AWS Firewall Manager returns a NextToken value in the response that allows you to list another group of PolicyComplianceStatus objects. For the second and subsequent ListComplianceStatus requests, specify the value of NextToken from the previous response to get information about another batch of PolicyComplianceStatus objects.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.ListComplianceStatusRequest.PolicyId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property PolicyId.
The ID of the AWS Firewall Manager policy that you want the details for.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.ListComplianceStatusResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the ListComplianceStatus operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.ListComplianceStatusResponse.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
If you have more PolicyComplianceStatus objects than the number that you specified for MaxResults in the request, the response includes a NextToken value. To list more PolicyComplianceStatus objects, submit another ListComplianceStatus request, and specify the NextToken value from the response in the NextToken value in the next request.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.ListComplianceStatusResponse.PolicyComplianceStatusList
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property PolicyComplianceStatusList.
An array of PolicyComplianceStatus objects.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.ListMemberAccountsRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the ListMemberAccounts operation. Returns a MemberAccounts object that lists the member accounts in the administrator's AWS organization.
The ListMemberAccounts must be submitted by the account that is set as the AWS Firewall Manager administrator.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.ListMemberAccountsRequest.MaxResults
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxResults.
Specifies the number of member account IDs that you want AWS Firewall Manager to return for this request. If you have more IDs than the number that you specify for MaxResults, the response includes a NextToken value that you can use to get another batch of member account IDs.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.ListMemberAccountsRequest.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
If you specify a value for MaxResults and you have more account IDs than the number that you specify for MaxResults, AWS Firewall Manager returns a NextToken value in the response that allows you to list another group of IDs. For the second and subsequent ListMemberAccountsRequest requests, specify the value of NextToken from the previous response to get information about another batch of member account IDs.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.ListMemberAccountsResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the ListMemberAccounts operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.ListMemberAccountsResponse.MemberAccounts
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MemberAccounts.
An array of account IDs.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.ListMemberAccountsResponse.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
If you have more member account IDs than the number that you specified for MaxResults in the request, the response includes a NextToken value. To list more IDs, submit another ListMemberAccounts request, and specify the NextToken value from the response in the NextToken value in the next request.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.ListPoliciesRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the ListPolicies operation. Returns an array of PolicySummary objects in the response.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.ListPoliciesRequest.MaxResults
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxResults.
Specifies the number of PolicySummary objects that you want AWS Firewall Manager to return for this request. If you have more PolicySummary objects than the number that you specify for MaxResults, the response includes a NextToken value that you can use to get another batch of PolicySummary objects.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.ListPoliciesRequest.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
If you specify a value for MaxResults and you have more PolicySummary objects than the number that you specify for MaxResults, AWS Firewall Manager returns a NextToken value in the response that allows you to list another group of PolicySummary objects. For the second and subsequent ListPolicies requests, specify the value of NextToken from the previous response to get information about another batch of PolicySummary objects.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.ListPoliciesResponse

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.ListPoliciesResponse.NextToken

If you have more PolicySummary objects than the number that you specified for MaxResults in the request, the response includes a NextToken value. To list more PolicySummary objects, submit another ListPolicies request, and specify the NextToken value from the response in the NextToken value in the next request.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.ListPoliciesResponse.PolicyList
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property PolicyList.
An array of PolicySummary objects.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.Policy
member.summary: An AWS Firewall Manager policy.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.Policy.ExcludeMap
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ExcludeMap.
Specifies the AWS account IDs to exclude from the policy. The IncludeMap values are evaluated first, with all the appropriate account IDs added to the policy. Then the accounts listed in ExcludeMap are removed, resulting in the final list of accounts to add to the policy.
The key to the map is ACCOUNT. For example, a valid ExcludeMap would be {“ACCOUNT” : [“accountID1”, “accountID2”]}.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.Policy.ExcludeResourceTags
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ExcludeResourceTags.
If set to True, resources with the tags that are specified in the ResourceTag array are not in scope of the policy. If set to False, and the ResourceTag array is not null, only resources with the specified tags are in scope of the policy.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.Policy.IncludeMap
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property IncludeMap.
Specifies the AWS account IDs to include in the policy. If IncludeMap is null, all accounts in the organization in AWS Organizations are included in the policy. If IncludeMap is not null, only values listed in IncludeMap are included in the policy.
The key to the map is ACCOUNT. For example, a valid IncludeMap would be {“ACCOUNT” : [“accountID1”, “accountID2”]}.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.Policy.PolicyId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property PolicyId.
The ID of the AWS Firewall Manager policy.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.Policy.PolicyName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property PolicyName.
The friendly name of the AWS Firewall Manager policy.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.Policy.PolicyUpdateToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property PolicyUpdateToken.
A unique identifier for each update to the policy. When issuing a PutPolicy request, the PolicyUpdateToken in the request must match the PolicyUpdateToken of the current policy version. To get the PolicyUpdateToken of the current policy version, use a GetPolicy request.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.Policy.RemediationEnabled
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RemediationEnabled.
Indicates if the policy should be automatically applied to new resources.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.Policy.ResourceTags
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ResourceTags.
An array of ResourceTag objects.

member.name: P:Amazon.FMS.Model.Policy.ResourceType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ResourceType.
The type of resource protected by or in scope of the policy. This is in the format shown in the AWS Resource Types Reference. For AWS WAF and Shield Advanced, examples include AWS::ElasticLoadBalancingV2::LoadBalancer and AWS::CloudFront::Distribution. For a security group common policy, valid values are AWS::EC2::NetworkInterface and AWS::EC2::Instance. For a security group content audit policy, valid values are AWS::EC2::SecurityGroup, AWS::EC2::NetworkInterface, and AWS::EC2::Instance. For a security group usage audit policy, the value is AWS::EC2::SecurityGroup.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.PutPolicyRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the PutPolicy operation. Creates an AWS Firewall Manager policy.
Firewall Manager provides the following types of policies:
A Shield Advanced policy, which applies Shield Advanced protection to specified accounts and resources
An AWS WAF policy, which contains a rule group and defines which resources are to be protected by that rule group
A security group policy, which manages VPC security groups across your AWS organization.
Each policy is specific to one of the three types. If you want to enforce more than one policy type across accounts, you can create multiple policies. You can create multiple policies for each type.
You must be subscribed to Shield Advanced to create a Shield Advanced policy. For more information about subscribing to Shield Advanced, see CreateSubscription.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.Model.ResourceTag
member.summary: The resource tags that AWS Firewall Manager uses to determine if a particular resource should be included or excluded from the AWS Firewall Manager policy. Tags enable you to categorize your AWS resources in different ways, for example, by purpose, owner, or environment. Each tag consists of a key and an optional value. Firewall Manager combines the tags with "AND" so that, if you add more than one tag to a policy scope, a resource must have all the specified tags to be included or excluded. For more information, see Working with Tag Editor.

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.AmazonFMSClient
member.summary:
Implementation for accessing FMS
AWS Firewall Manager
This is the AWS Firewall Manager API Reference. This guide is for developers who need detailed information about the AWS Firewall Manager API actions, data types, and errors. For detailed information about AWS Firewall Manager features, see the AWS Firewall Manager Developer Guide.

member.name: M:Amazon.FMS.AmazonFMSClient.#ctor
member.summary:
Constructs AmazonFMSClient with the credentials loaded from the application's default configuration, and if unsuccessful from the Instance Profile service on an EC2 instance.

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="AWSProfileName" value="AWS Default"/> </appSettings> </configuration>

member.name: M:Amazon.FMS.AmazonFMSClient.AssociateAdminAccountAsync(Amazon.FMS.Model.AssociateAdminAccountRequest,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary:
Sets the AWS Firewall Manager administrator account. AWS Firewall Manager must be associated with the master account of your AWS organization or associated with a member account that has the appropriate permissions. If the account ID that you submit is not an AWS Organizations master account, AWS Firewall Manager will set the appropriate permissions for the given member account.
The account that you associate with AWS Firewall Manager is called the AWS Firewall Manager administrator account.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the AssociateAdminAccount service method.
A cancellation token that can be used by other objects or threads to receive notice of cancellation.
member.returns: The response from the AssociateAdminAccount service method, as returned by FMS.
member.exception: The operation failed because of a system problem, even though the request was valid. Retry your request.
The parameters of the request were invalid.

The operation failed because there was nothing to do. For example, you might have submitted an AssociateAdminAccount request, but the account ID that you submitted was already set as the AWS Firewall Manager administrator.
The specified resource was not found.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for AssociateAdminAccount Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.FMS.AmazonFMSClient.PutPolicyAsync(Amazon.FMS.Model.PutPolicyRequest,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary:
Creates an AWS Firewall Manager policy.
Firewall Manager provides the following types of policies:
A Shield Advanced policy, which applies Shield Advanced protection to specified accounts and resources
An AWS WAF policy, which contains a rule group and defines which resources are to be protected by that rule group
A security group policy, which manages VPC security groups across your AWS organization.
Each policy is specific to one of the three types. If you want to enforce more than one policy type across accounts, you can create multiple policies. You can create multiple policies for each type.
You must be subscribed to Shield Advanced to create a Shield Advanced policy. For more information about subscribing to Shield Advanced, see CreateSubscription.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the PutPolicy service method.
A cancellation token that can be used by other objects or threads to receive notice of cancellation.
member.returns: The response from the PutPolicy service method, as returned by FMS.
member.exception: The operation failed because of a system problem, even though the request was valid. Retry your request.
The parameters of the request were invalid.

The operation failed because there was nothing to do. For example, you might have submitted an AssociateAdminAccount request, but the account ID that you submitted was already set as the AWS Firewall Manager administrator.
The value of the Type parameter is invalid.

The operation exceeds a resource limit, for example, the maximum number of policy objects that you can create for an AWS account. For more information, see Firewall Manager Limits in the AWS WAF Developer Guide.
The specified resource was not found.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for PutPolicy Operation

member.name: T:Amazon.FMS.IAmazonFMS
member.summary:
Interface for accessing FMS
AWS Firewall Manager
This is the AWS Firewall Manager API Reference. This guide is for developers who need detailed information about the AWS Firewall Manager API actions, data types, and errors. For detailed information about AWS Firewall Manager features, see the AWS Firewall Manager Developer Guide.

member.name: M:Amazon.FMS.IAmazonFMS.AssociateAdminAccountAsync(Amazon.FMS.Model.AssociateAdminAccountRequest,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary:
Sets the AWS Firewall Manager administrator account. AWS Firewall Manager must be associated with the master account of your AWS organization or associated with a member account that has the appropriate permissions. If the account ID that you submit is not an AWS Organizations master account, AWS Firewall Manager will set the appropriate permissions for the given member account.
The account that you associate with AWS Firewall Manager is called the AWS Firewall Manager administrator account.
